title: 11 Easy Steps to Clean a Laser Printer

steps.title: Leave the printer unplugged for at least 1 hour prior to cleaning.
steps.content: Leave the printer unplugged for at least 1 hour prior to cleaning. This gives the parts time to cool down and helps prevent electrical shocks.

steps.title: Review your owner's manual to determine how the printer should be opened.
steps.content: Review your owner's manual to determine how the printer should be opened. Some printers have latches; some open on a hinge; and others might require a screwdriver.

steps.title: To properly clean the printer, you'll want to remove all parts that can be removed.
steps.content: To properly clean the printer, you'll want to remove all parts that can be removed. The removable parts will vary depending on your model. Find and lift out the all-in-one toner cartridge if your laser printer is newer and relatively inexpensive. Take out the imaging drum. It is usually a bright green or blue color. Grab each side of the drum; do not touch the surface of the drum. Carefully lift out the imaging drum and place it in an area with no light.

steps.title: Wipe the toner cartridge or bottle with an activated toner cloth.
steps.content: Wipe the toner cartridge or bottle with an activated toner cloth. Toner cloth is specially designed to attract and catch toner particles that other cloths would leave behind. Rest the cartridge on another toner cloth.

steps.title: Position a toner vacuum into the printer chassis.
steps.content: Position a toner vacuum into the printer chassis. Move the vacuum nozzle around slowly, lingering for at least 3 seconds for each crevice. This sucks out any spilled toner you see in the interior.

steps.title: Use a clean paintbrush to reach tight areas.
steps.content: Use a clean paintbrush to reach tight areas. Scrub the corners gently to loosen any built-up toner. Vacuum out the debris the paintbrush loosens.

steps.title: You'll want to use a cotton swab dipped in rubbing alcohol.
steps.content: You'll want to use a cotton swab dipped in rubbing alcohol. Dip a cotton swab into rubbing alcohol, and then: Find the exposed fine wires inside the printer. They are usually near the paper rollers. Their purpose is to attract toner by transferring a static charge to the paper. Rub the swab across the wires, twisting the swab when one side becomes soiled.

steps.title: It's best to do this with a can of compressed air.
steps.content: It's best to do this with a can of compressed air. Spray compressed air in short quick bursts near the internal fan from several inches away.

steps.title: Remove toner that has gathered on the roller.
steps.content: Remove toner that has gathered on the roller. You can do this by pouring rubbing alcohol on a cotton swab and scrubbing the roller in a circular motion.

steps.title: Use a micro-fiber cloth and rubbing alcohol to clean the outer parts.
steps.content: Use a micro-fiber cloth and rubbing alcohol to clean the outer parts. This gives the external surface a nice clean look.

steps.title: Allow any parts that are damp to fully dry before replacing the parts.
steps.content: Allow any parts that are damp to fully dry before replacing the parts. Once you've reassembled your nice-and-clean printer, you can turn it back on and start printing.
